title: An Unusual Case of Fluctuating Hearing Loss
chief_complaint: I have roaring and ringing noises in my ears, and my hearing seems to fluctuate. I also get dizzy spells where the room spins.

problem_summary.onset: Symptoms began 1 year prior to the initial appointment.
problem_summary.course: Fluctuating symptoms; hearing loss and tinnitus increase prior to vertigo episodes. Symptoms improve near the middle of the menstrual cycle, while balance symptoms worsen around her period.
problem_summary.laterality: Bilateral (tinnitus: left roaring, right ringing; hearing loss: bilateral).
problem_summary.associated_symptoms: Spinning vertigo (30 mins to 1-2 days), migraine headaches with visual aura, anxiety, hyperhidrosis.
problem_summary.functional_impact: Hearing difficulty and dizziness affecting daily life.
problem_summary.goals_motivation: Seeking diagnosis and management for fluctuating hearing and vertigo.

history.present_illness: Patient reports roaring tinnitus (left) and ringing tinnitus (right) varying daily. Episodes of spinning vertigo. Symptoms fluctuate with menstrual cycle.
history.medical_psych_history: Migraine with aura, anxiety, hyperhidrosis. Meds: pentoxifylline, HCTZ, diazepam, Paxil.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Right ear: Moderate SNHL 250-1000 Hz, rising to mild at 1500 Hz, normal at 2000-3000 Hz, sloping to mild-moderate SNHL 4000-8000 Hz. Left ear: Mild SNHL 250-500 Hz, normal 750-3000 Hz, slight SNHL 4000-8000 Hz.

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.key_findings: SRT revealed mild loss in right ear and normal ability in left ear. WRS normal in both ears.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Right ear: Significantly poorer hearing at 3000-4000 Hz and 8000 Hz. Left ear: Significantly poorer hearing from 250 to 8000 Hz.

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.key_findings: SRT revealed mild loss (Right) and moderate loss (Left). WRS normal (Right) and slight difficulty (Left).

history.present_illness: Patient is in first pregnancy (31-week gestation).

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Right ear: Significantly improved hearing at 250-1000 Hz and 3000-8000 Hz. Left ear: No significant change except 15 dB improvement at 1500 Hz.

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.key_findings: Right SRT normal; Left SRT mild loss. WRS normal (Right) and slight difficulty (Left).

history.present_illness: 3 months post-delivery of first baby. Hearing worsened approx 1 week after delivery.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Right ear: Significantly poorer hearing at 1000 Hz and 3000-8000 Hz compared to pregnancy. Left ear: Relatively unchanged.

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.key_findings: Mild SRT loss bilaterally. WRS did not significantly change.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Air conduction thresholds relatively unchanged. Left WRS significantly poorer.

history.present_illness: Patient is in second pregnancy (24-week gestation).

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Right ear: Significantly improved thresholds 250-8000 Hz. Left ear: Not significantly different.

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.key_findings: Right ear: Normal ability to receive/recognize speech. Left ear: Moderately severe loss (SRT) and poor recognition.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Right ear: Significantly poorer from 250-1500 Hz and 6000-8000 Hz. Left ear: Thresholds not significantly different.

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.key_findings: Right WRS decreased. Left WRS improved.

overall_audiologic_summary: The patient exhibits bilateral, asymmetric, fluctuating sensorineural hearing loss. The hearing loss configuration is generally low-frequency or flat, with significant fluctuations correlated with hormonal status (improving during pregnancy, worsening post-partum). Speech recognition scores also fluctuate, particularly in the left ear, ranging from good to poor depending on the visit.
counseling_points: Your hearing loss and dizziness appear linked to hormonal changes, as evidenced by improvements during pregnancy.
There is significant overlap between Vestibular Migraine and Meniere's Disease; your symptoms suggest features of both.
Dietary triggers, such as caffeine and salt, may influence your symptoms and should be monitored.
Because your hearing fluctuates, hearing aids with multiple programs or volume control flexibility will be important to accommodate 'good' and 'bad' hearing days.
notes_for_actor: Portray anxiety about the unpredictability of the vertigo and hearing loss.
Mention that you feel much better when pregnant, but the symptoms crash back after the baby is born.
Emphasize the roaring sound in your left ear as very distracting.
